content.text: Wild rifts lead elsewhere. When a wild rift opens and the crew steps through, the GM builds whatever they want. The cataloged dimensions are templates.

Guidelines for creating dimensions: 1. One dominant feature. Describable in one sentence. “The volcanic one.“ “The wrong one.“ 2. One unique hazard. Heat, gravity, time, atmosphere, psychology — pick one. 3. Resources that match a corp. At least one corp should want what’s inside. 4. Three tiers of fauna. One T1, one T2, one T3+. Use the Enemy Creation framework. 5. A mystery. Something unexplained. A structure, a species, a resource that does something unexpected. The subplot seed. “Dimensional exploration is not recreation. It is resource acquisition in a non-standard operating environment. If you find the experience ’awe-inspiring’ or ’existentially overwhelming,’ please report these responses to your post-mission psychological screening. They are normal. They are also billable.“

“Extended deployment authorization granted. Supply requisition Form 19-C must be filed 48 hours prior to gate entry. Intercompany Logistics assumes no liability for supply shortfalls, dimensional contamination, or crew losses exceeding 40% of deployed personnel.“
Expedition Overview

Not every rift job is a quick smash-and-grab. Some contracts require days inside a dimension — deep extraction runs, survey missions, artifact recovery from hostile territory. These expeditions test more than combat skill. They test preparation, resource management, and the crew’s ability to know when to push forward and when to pull out.

The rift is not a dungeon. It’s a hostile environment that is actively poisoning you. Every hour you spend inside increases the contamination seeping into your body. Every night you sleep there, the dimension gets a little more familiar with you — and you get a little less human. The longer you stay, the more the rift pushes back.
The Expedition Day
Each day in a rift follows a structured cycle:

Dawn Phase — Wake, break camp, consume rations, plan the day’s route. Travel Phase — Move through the rift toward your objective. Encounter checks happen here. Activity Phase — Explore, fight, loot, complete objectives. The bulk of play. Camp Phase — Find shelter, set up equipment, post watch, rest.
A crew can choose to skip the Camp Phase and push through the night, but fatigue penalties accumulate fast.
Supplies & Resources
Rations
Every contractor consumes 1 Ration per day. A Ration represents food and water combined — compressed nutri-packs, purified water tabs, and calorie bars. Standard contractor fare.
Item Weight Cost Notes
Ration (1 day)    0.5               5 cr              1 per person per day
Ration Pack (5    2                 20 cr             Bulk discount days)

Expedition Crate  6                 70 cr             Requires vehicle (20 days)                                             or pack animal to haul ----------------- ----------------- ----------------- -----------------

Missing a Ration: A contractor who goes without food/water for a day takes -1 to all checks the following day. Two consecutive days without: -2 to all checks and lose 1 HP per hour of travel. Three days: Exhaustion (see Conditions).
Foraging: A contractor can attempt to find food/water in-rift with a

Resilience check (DC varies by dimension). On a full success, find 1d4 Rations worth of edible material. On partial, find 1 Ration but gain +1 Toxicity (the food is… not quite right). On failure, nothing — and you wasted the time.

Environmental Exposure
Passive Toxicity
Simply being inside a rift dimension contaminates you. Every day spent in-rift, each contractor gains passive Toxicity based on the dimension’s hostility level.
Dimension Rating Passive Tox/Day Examples
Mild +1 The Bloom (outer regions), stable gates
Moderate +2 The Brine, The Bloom (deep), The Mirror
Harsh +3 The Char, The Grave
Extreme +5 The Static, unstable rifts, uncharted dimensions
Terminal +8 Deep Static, rift storms, collapsing dimensions ----------------------- ----------------------- -----------------------
Passive Toxicity is applied during the Dawn Phase each day. It cannot be avoided by staying still — the dimension itself is toxic.
Environmental Hazards
Beyond passive Toxicity, each dimension has environmental effects that worsen over time.

The Bloom: Spore saturation. After Day 3, Resilience check (DC 8) each morning or gain a random minor mutation (temporary, fades 1d4 days after extraction). After Day 5, the DC increases to 10 and mutations may become permanent.

The Char: Heat and ash. -1 to all physical checks after Day 2 from dehydration and heat exhaustion. Water consumption doubles (2 Rations/day or 1 Ration + extra water). After Day 4, unprotected equipment degrades — weapons lose 1 damage die until repaired.
The Brine: Corrosion. Armor degrades by 1 point per 3 days unless treated with anti-corrosive (30 cr per application, 1 per 3 days). After Day 5, metal weapons are affected too.
The Grave: Psychic pressure. Edge checks (DC 7) each night or suffer nightmares — no HP recovery from rest. After Day 3, failed checks also cause -1 to Edge until extraction.

The Static:∗∗ Reality erosion. The most dangerous rift to camp in. Sleeping in the Static requires an Interface check (DC 8) or your equipment malfunctions — one random item stops working until a Tech check (DC 8) is passed. After Day 2, the DC increases to 10. After Day 4: DC 12, and failed checks cause 1d4 damage as reality stutters around you. ∗∗The Static is designed to be a sprint, not a camping trip.

The Mirror: Identity drift. After Day 2, Grit check (DC 7) each morning. Failure means you see/hear things that aren’t there — -2 to Awareness checks until you pass a rest check. After Day 5, failed checks cause temporary personality shifts (GM discretion — play these for dark comedy).

Rest & Recovery
Short Rest (1 hour)
A quick breather between encounters. No camp required.
• Recover 25% of max HP (round up) • No Toxicity recovery • Can use Healing Stims, Scrubbers, etc. • Costs 1 hour of travel time — the crew stops moving • Cannot Short Rest more than twice per day

Short Rests are a trade-off between healing and progress. An hour spent resting is an hour not spent covering ground — and on a timed expedition, that gap adds up. A crew on foot loses a significant chunk of their daily travel to a single rest stop. A crew in a fast vehicle can absorb the time more easily, which is one of the key advantages of vehicular transport.
Long Rest (8 hours — 6 sleep + 2 watch)
Setting up camp and sleeping. Requires a reasonably safe location.
Base Recovery: • Recover 50% of max HP (round up) • No Toxicity recovery (without augments or equipment) • Consume 1 Ration

Watch Rotation: A crew of 4 should post 2-hour watches. Each contractor takes one watch shift and sleeps 6 hours. A contractor on watch does not recover HP during their shift — they recover during sleep only. A crew that doesn’t post watch risks ambush (see Encounter Escalation).
Interrupted Rest: If combat occurs during a Long Rest, the rest is ruined for anyone who participated in the fight. They recover only 25% HP (as Short Rest) and still consume the Ration.
Rest Degradation
The longer you stay in a rift, the worse rest becomes. The dimension seeps into your sleep.
Days In-Rift HP Recovery (Long Additional Effects Rest)
Day 1-2                 50% max HP              Normal rest
Day 3-4                 40% max HP              Fitful sleep. -1 to first check of the day.
Day 5-6                 30% max HP              Nightmares. Grit check DC 6 or gain +1 Toxicity overnight.
Day 7-9                 25% max HP              Rift dreams. Grit check DC 8 or gain +2 Toxicity overnight. -1 to all checks until noon.

Day 10+                 15% max HP              The rift knows you. Grit check DC 10 or gain +3 Toxicity overnight. Permanent -1 to Edge until extraction. ----------------------- ----------------------- -----------------------
Rift Meditation (Channeler T2 Augment): During Long Rest, purge Toxicity equal to your Interface bonus. Only works below 75% Toxicity. Once per rest.
Pressure Vent (Leech T2 Augment): During Long Rest, purge Toxicity equal to your Grit bonus. Take 1d4 damage (unpreventable). Works at any Toxicity level. Once per rest.
Scrub Station Treatment: Can be used during Long Rest without reducing rest quality. The medic applies treatment while others sleep.
Travel
Travel Speed

Movement through rift dimensions is measured in zones per hour. A “zone“ is an abstract unit — a distinct area with its own features, hazards, and potential encounters. GMs define the zone layout for each expedition.
Base Travel Speeds:
Mode Zones/Hour Daily Max (10hr Notes travel day)
On Foot 0.5 5 zones Standard walking pace. Exhausting over distance.
Pack Animal 0.5 5 zones Same speed as walking, but carries 20 extra weight.
Crawler (Light 1 10 zones Basic rift Vehicle) transport. Fits 4 + cargo.
Hauler (Heavy 0.75 7 zones Slower but Vehicle) massive cargo capacity (50+). Carries expedition equipment.
Runner (Fast 1.5 15 zones Speed-built. Fits Vehicle) 2-3 + light cargo. Reaches objectives fast.
APC (Armored 1 10 zones Crawler speed + Vehicle) armor. Crew can Short Rest inside while moving (driver excluded). ----------------- ----------------- ----------------- -----------------

Why speed matters: A 10-zone expedition on foot takes 2 full travel days. In a Runner, it takes 7 hours — less than a single day. That’s one fewer night of rest degradation, one fewer day of passive Toxicity, one fewer day of encounter escalation. Speed doesn’t just save time — it saves resources, health, and lives.
Short Rests and travel: A Short Rest takes 1 hour. On foot, that’s

0.5 zones of lost progress. In a Runner, that’s 1.5 zones lost. The faster you travel, the more ground a rest stop costs — but you have more margin to absorb it. An APC is the exception: non-driver crew members can rest inside a moving APC without stopping.
Terrain Modifiers
Terrain reduces travel speed. Apply the modifier to base speed (minimum
0.25 zones/hour).
Terrain Type Speed Modifier Examples
Open ×1 (full speed) Bloom plains, Brine shallows, Mirror flatlands
Rough ×0.5 Char wastelands, Bloom jungle, Grave ruins
Difficult ×0.25 Static fractured terrain, deep Grave catacombs, Brine trenches
Impassable ×0 (must find alternate Collapsed passages, route) reality tears, dimensional walls
Vehicle-Hostile Vehicles cannot enter. Narrow passages, On foot only at ×0.5. vertical climbs, unstable floors ----------------------- ----------------------- -----------------------

Example: A crew in a Crawler (1 zone/hr) enters Rough terrain. Speed drops to 0.5 zones/hr. In 10 hours of travel, they cover 5 zones — same as on foot in Open terrain. The Crawler’s advantage disappears in bad terrain, but it still carries the crew’s supplies.
Example: A Runner (1.5 zones/hr) on Open terrain covers 15 zones in a day. The same Runner in Rough terrain covers 7.5. Still faster than walking, but the advantage narrows.
Forced March
A crew can push beyond normal travel distance by skipping the Camp Phase.
Forced March: Travel 1 additional zone. Each contractor makes a
Grit check (DC 7). On failure: Exhaustion. On partial: -1 to all checks the next day. Cannot Force March two days in a row.
Navigation
Getting lost in a rift wastes time and supplies. The crew’s navigator makes an Awareness check at the start of each Travel Phase.
Result Effect
10+ On course. Arrive at intended destination. May spot shortcuts or avoid hazards.
7-9 Arrive but with complications. Minor detour (half a zone wasted), unexpected encounter, or arrive at the wrong entrance to the target area.
6- Lost. Waste a full zone of travel. Additional encounter check. Supplies consumed for the wasted time. ----------------------------------- -----------------------------------
Rift Lore T2+ grants advantage on navigation checks. A crew without a trained navigator is playing with fire on long expeditions.
Encounter Escalation
The rift pushes back harder the longer you stay. This is represented by the Intensity Track — a rising threat level that determines encounter frequency and difficulty.
Intensity Track
Days In-Rift Intensity Encounter Enemy Chance/Zone Adjustment
Day 1 Low 20% per zone Standard enemies traveled
Day 2 Low 25% per zone Standard enemies traveled
Day 3 Rising 35% per zone +1 enemy per traveled encounter
Day 4 Rising 40% per zone +1 enemy, Elites traveled appear
Day 5 High 50% per zone +2 enemies, traveled Elites common
Day 6 High 55% per zone +2 enemies, traveled Boss-tier possible
Day 7+ Critical 65% per zone +3 enemies, traveled Boss-tier common, Hordes double size ----------------- ----------------- ----------------- -----------------

Encounter checks: Roll d100 at the start of each zone of travel. If the roll is at or below the encounter chance, a combat encounter occurs. The GM determines the specific enemies based on the dimension and Intensity level.
Night encounters: If the crew is camping, roll one encounter check per night at half the normal encounter chance. Posting watch means the crew isn’t surprised. No watch = surprise round for enemies.
Stealth modifier: If the crew is actively moving stealthily (half travel speed), reduce encounter chance by 10%. A Stealth-focused crew trades time for safety.
Intensity Spikes
Certain actions increase Intensity faster:

Camping in an unsecured location    Double night encounter chance

Expedition Planning
Supply Calculation Worksheet
Before entering a rift, the crew should calculate their supply needs:

Per Person Per Day: • 1 Ration (5 cr, 0.5 weight) • 1 Purification Tab or Purifier charge (1.5 cr) • 1 Enviro Seal every 3 days (13 cr/day average) OR Hazard Suit for 5 days (50 cr/day average) Per Person, Bring Along: • 2-4 Healing Stims (100-200 cr) • 1-2 Toxicity Scrubbers (75-150 cr) Crew Shared (optional but recommended): • Trauma Kit (150 cr, 3 charges) • Scrubber Kit (300 cr, 5 charges) • Shelter Kit (80 cr) • Fuel Cells for Tox Shield (80 cr each)
Example: 5-Day Expedition, 4-Person Crew

Supply Quantity Cost Weight

Enviro Seals      8 (4 people × 2   320 cr            0 sets of 3 days)

The difference between minimum and recommended is the difference between surviving and operating comfortably. Most crews start at minimum and invest in expedition gear over time as contracts pay out. The Tox Shield alone costs more than a starting contractor’s entire loadout — but it’s what lets you stay in a rift for a week instead of three days.

This is where vehicles matter. A crew on foot carrying 39 weight of expedition supplies is barely functional. A crew with a Crawler (Cargo 50) hauls everything they need and more. Vehicles aren’t luxury — they’re expedition infrastructure.
Extraction
Planned Extraction

The crew’s contract specifies an extraction point and timeline. Reaching the extraction point triggers the end of the expedition. If the crew has a Signal Booster, they can call for early extraction — but the extraction team takes 1d4 hours to arrive. Hold your position.
Emergency Extraction

When things go sideways, getting out means tearing a rift at your current location. You don’t teleport back to a gate — you punch through the dimensional membrane right where you’re standing and step into realspace at approximately the same geographic position. The problem is “approximately.“ Without a stabilized gate, the exit point is imprecise. You could emerge a few blocks from where you intended, or a few miles. In the wrong neighborhood, the wrong district, or the wrong side of a corporate border.
Gate Beacon (one-time use, 500 cr, Weight 1)
A portable device that forces a dimensional crossing at your location.

• Controlled Activation (3 turns): The beacon charges over 3 combat turns (or \~30 seconds out of combat). It emits a visible/audible pulse each turn — enemies in the area will converge on your position. On Turn 3, a rift tears open. The portal lasts 10 minutes. You exit into realspace within 1d4 blocks of your approximate position. Close enough to orient yourself. Everyone goes through or gets left behind. • Forced Activation (1 turn): Slam the overcharge. The portal opens immediately — but it’s violent. Roll d100 on the Violent Extraction Chaos Table. The crew exits into realspace within 1d4 kilometers of your approximate position — sewer, rooftop, warehouse, corporate territory, or worse. What happens during transit is not predictable. The beacon is destroyed either way.
The beacon is consumed on use. This is the emergency eject — expensive, single-use, and everyone in the rift knows you just lit a dimensional flare.
Rift Walk (Rift Lore T3)
A trained rift navigator can feel the dimensional membrane and force a crossing by hand.

• Controlled Crossing (3 turns + Interface check DC 10): The navigator spends 3 turns reading the dimensional fabric and carefully threading a passage. On success, a stable portal opens for 5 minutes. You exit into realspace within 1 block of your approximate position — a skilled navigator can feel where the membrane is thinnest. On partial (7-9), the exit drifts — 1d4 blocks away, possibly in an inconvenient location. On failure, no portal — and the navigator takes 2d4 Toxicity from the strain. • Violent Tear (1 turn + Interface check DC 12): The navigator rips reality open by force. On success, the portal opens immediately — roll d100 on the Violent Extraction Chaos Table and exit 1d4 kilometers away in realspace. On partial (7-9), the tear goes sideways — you exit into a different rift dimension instead of realspace (you escaped one rift into another). On failure, no portal, the navigator takes 3d6 Toxicity, and the tear attracts a Boss-tier encounter.

Why gates exist: This is exactly why corporations build stabilized gates. A gate locks the entry and exit points, eliminates drift, and provides a safe corridor between dimensions. Tearing a rift without a gate is like jumping out of a moving vehicle instead of waiting for it to stop. You’ll probably survive. You won’t enjoy the landing. And wherever you land, you still need to get home.

Short-Distance Rift Hopping: Some crews use beacons or Rift Walk for tactical repositioning — hopping into a rift and back out a few zones away to bypass dangerous terrain or enemy positions. Each hop tears a rift at your location, moves you through the dimensional space, and tears another rift to exit. Both entry and exit points drift. Over short distances the drift is manageable (1d4 blocks). Over longer distances, you’re rolling the dice on where you come out. Useful for desperate repositioning, terrible for precision movement.
Expedition Pacing Guide (For GMs)
First Expedition (Session 1-2 tutorial)

• Duration: 1 day in-rift  • Zones: 2-3  • Encounters: 1-2 (scripted, not random)  • Purpose: Teach combat, basic rift flavor  • Supplies: Pre-packed by the contract holder (don’t make players shop yet)  • Toxicity: Minimal (Mild dimension, 1 day)  • No camping required
Second Expedition (Session 3-5 — the real one)

• Duration: 3-4 days in-rift  • Zones: 6-10  • Encounters: 4-8 (mix of random and scripted)  • Purpose: Full expedition experience — resource management, camping, escalation  • Supplies: Players must purchase and plan  • Toxicity: Meaningful (Moderate dimension, multi-day)  • At least 2 camp phases  • At least 1 night encounter  • Intensity reaches Rising by the end
Deep Expedition (Later arcs)

• Duration: 5-7+ days  • Zones: 10-20+  • Encounters: 8-15+  • Purpose: Major contract, serious stakes  • Supplies: Significant investment, vehicle recommended  • Toxicity: Dangerous (Harsh+ dimensions)  • Full escalation curve  • Environmental hazards become major factors  • Extraction planning matters

A 5-day expedition costs a crew roughly 800 cr in consumables alone — before healing supplies, ammo, and equipment. The contract better pay well.

This is the money trap. Longer contracts pay more but cost more to supply. A crew that doesn’t invest in expedition infrastructure (Tox Shield, Scrub Station, Fortified Shelter) can only sustain 3-4 day operations. A crew that invests heavily can push to 7+ days — unlocking the deep contracts that pay 5,000+ cr. But the upfront cost of that infrastructure is 3,000-5,000 cr. You have to earn it.
Welcome to the rift economy.
“Don’t use violent extraction unless you’re already dead. Because what comes out the other side might be worse.“
How Violent Extraction Works

When a contractor triggers a Violent Extraction — whether through a Gate Beacon’s emergency mode or a Rift Walk forced cast — the portal tears open instantly with no stabilization. The crew tumbles through a raw dimensional rift.
There is no damage roll. Instead, roll d100 on the Chaos Table. What happens is what happens.
The GM rolls once for the whole crew. Everyone experiences the same event. Individual saves or checks may apply within the result.
Exit location is random. The crew appears within 1d4 kilometers of their approximate real-world position. Where exactly within that radius is the GM’s call.
The Chaos Table (d100)
01-05 — Miraculous
Against all odds, you got lucky.
Roll Result
01 Perfect Exit. You emerge exactly where you intended, no drift, no side effects. The rift was clean. Don’t get used to it.
02 Dimensional Gift. You come through carrying something extra — a chunk of crystallized rift energy worth 500 cr, lodged in someone’s pack. Wasn’t there before.

03 Temporal Skip. You exit 1d4 hours before you entered. Brief window of paradox — you could warn yourselves, set up an ambush at the extraction point, or prepare for what’s coming. GM decides how reality handles it.
04 Cleansed. The rift transit burned the toxicity out of your systems. Every crew member drops to 0 Toxicity. You feel better than you have in weeks.

05 Rift Echo. A ghostly duplicate of the most dangerous enemy you fought this mission appears, fights the nearest hostile NPC for 1d4 rounds, then dissolves. Thanks, dimensional chaos. ----------------------------------- -----------------------------------
06-20 — Lucky (Minor Inconvenience)
You got through. Some weirdness, nothing lethal.
Roll Result
06-07 Nausea Wave. Everyone vomits. -1 to all checks for 1 hour. Unpleasant but functional.
08-09 Rift Static. All electronic equipment is scrambled. Comms, targeting systems, neural jacks — all offline for 1d4 hours. Reboot required.
10-11 Time Stutter. You lose 1d6 hours. You exited later than you should have. Clients might be angry. Night might have fallen.
12-13 Cosmetic Mutation. One random crew member’s appearance changes — eye color, hair texture, skin pigmentation, minor facial features. Permanent but harmless.

14-15 Phantom Sounds. For the next 24 hours, the crew hears sounds from the dimension they just left. Bloom spores rustling. Char flames crackling. Static buzzing. Distracting but not dangerous. -1 to Awareness checks.
16-17 Magnetic Anomaly. All metal objects the crew is carrying are weakly magnetized for 1d4 days. Weapons stick to each other, ammo clusters, doors are annoying.

18-19 Memory Flash. Each crew member experiences a vivid memory that isn’t theirs — someone else’s life, from a dimension they’ve never visited. Could be useful lore. Could be disturbing. GM provides a brief scene.

20 Gear Swap. Two random crew members’ inventories are swapped. They’re holding each other’s weapons, wearing each other’s armor. Everything still functions — it’s just in the wrong hands. Sort it out. ----------------------------------- -----------------------------------
21-45 — Rough (Moderate Consequences)
You made it. You’re not happy about it.
Roll Result
21-23 Toxicity Spike. Every crew member gains +1d6 Toxicity. The rift transit was contaminated.
24-26 Drift — Way Off. Exit point is 1d4+2 kilometers from intended position. You’re in an unfamiliar part of the city. Might be hostile territory.
27-29 Temporary Blindness. One random crew member is blinded for 1d4 hours. Rift flash burned their retinas. They need to be guided.
30-32 Equipment Damage. One random piece of equipment per crew member is damaged. Armor loses 1 point. Weapons jam (need repair before use). Electronics short out.
33-34 Rift Residue. The crew is coated in rift material. They glow faintly for 1d4 days. Stealth is impossible. Everyone can see you. Undercity contacts might avoid you (visible contamination).
35-37 Dimensional Jet Lag. The crew’s sleep cycles are inverted. For the next 3 days, they can only rest during the day and are alert at night. Social encounters during business hours are at -1.

38-39 Partial Transit. One random crew member’s gear didn’t make it through. Their inventory is empty — weapons, armor, pack, everything. The equipment is gone, scattered somewhere between dimensions.

40-42 Toxicity Scar. Each crew member gains a Toxicity Scar — a permanent mark of rift exposure that’s visible on their skin. Functions like a regular Scar for economic purposes (cost to treat). First one is free (cosmetic only). Subsequent ones stack normally.

43-45 Sensory Bleed. For 1d4 days, the crew’s senses randomly swap — seeing sounds, hearing colors, tasting textures. -2 to Awareness checks. Slowly fades. ----------------------------------- -----------------------------------
46-70 — Bad (Serious Consequences)
This is why they tell you not to do this.
Roll Result

46-48 Enemies Followed You. 1d4 enemies from the rift dimension exit the portal with you. They’re confused, aggressive, and now loose in the real world. Combat encounter, immediately, in whatever condition the crew is in.
49-51 Dimensional Sickness. Everyone gains +2d6 Toxicity AND one random crew member contracts a Dimensional Illness — persistent condition requiring medical treatment (500 cr) or it worsens daily.

52-54 Spatial Scatter. The crew is separated. Each member exits at a different point within a 2 km radius. They’re alone, in an unfamiliar area, and comms might not work (50% chance). Regroup takes 1d6 hours.
55-57 Time Skip — Forward. You exit 1d4 days later than you should have. The contract window has closed. Your clients think you’re dead. Someone may have already looted your safehouse.

58-59 Rift Anchor Left Behind. The portal didn’t close cleanly. A small, unstable rift remains at the exit point for 1d4 days. It attracts rift creatures and dimensional anomalies. You’ve created a problem in someone’s neighborhood. Gate Authority will investigate.

60-62 Augment Scramble. All augments on the crew malfunction for 1d4 days. Random effects — augment bonuses reversed, Leech burns trigger involuntarily, optical camo flickers constantly, neural jacks feed static.
63-65 Mutation. One random crew member gains a minor mutation. Roll on the Mutation table. This is permanent unless treated.
66-67 Gravity Inversion. The crew exits upside down, 3d6 meters in the air. They fall. Grit check (DC 8) or take 1d6 damage (armor doesn’t help — it’s a fall).

68-70 Rift Debt. The dimension noticed you leaving without permission. Something is now aware of the crew. For the next 1d4 expeditions, encounter rates are +10% and one encounter per expedition will be specifically targeting them. ----------------------------------- -----------------------------------
71-85 — Terrible (Major Consequences)
You survived. Barely. Things are very wrong.
Roll Result

71-73 Wrong Destination. You don’t exit in the real world. You exit in a different rift dimension. Roll on the Dimension table. You’re in a new dimension with whatever supplies you have left. You need to find another way out.
74-76 Crew Fractured. Half the crew exits normally. The other half exits in the wrong dimension (roll on Dimension table). Rescue mission required.

77-78 Temporal Echo. A copy of one random crew member from 1d4 hours in the past exits with the crew. The copy has all the gear and HP they had at that time. The copy is real, confused, and temporary — they dissolve in 1d4 hours. What they reveal about the recent past could be useful or deeply unsettling.
79-80 Massive Toxicity Spike. Everyone gains +3d6 Toxicity. Multiple crew members may cross thresholds. Someone might hit Harvest range. This is an emergency.

81-82 Possessed Equipment. One random piece of equipment gains sentience — or at least, something from the rift is living in it. The weapon whispers. The armor moves on its own. The neural jack plays memories that aren’t yours. Might be useful (the weapon warns of danger). Might be hostile (the armor tightens during sleep). Requires Rift Lore T2 to diagnose, 500 cr to exorcise.

83-84 Identity Bleed. Two crew members swap one memory each — a skill, a personal memory, a piece of knowledge. Mechanically: swap one skill rank between the two characters for 1d4 days. The memories come back, but slowly.

85 You Brought the Boss. Whatever the biggest threat was in the rift — the boss, the apex predator, the thing that was hunting you — it came through the portal with you. Full stat block. In the real world. In whatever neighborhood you landed in. People are going to die if you don’t deal with this now. ----------------------------------- -----------------------------------
86-95 — Catastrophic (Campaign-Altering)
The GM should prepare for these. They change the game.
Roll Result

86-88 Dimensional Merge. A chunk of the rift dimension merges with the real world around the exit point. A city block is now partially Bloom, Char, Brine, or whatever dimension you left. Permanent. Creatures, hazards, and materials from that dimension now exist in the real world. Gate Authority declares a quarantine zone. This is your fault.

89-91 Time Fracture. The crew exits at different points in time. Some arrive now. Some arrive 1d4 weeks in the past. Some arrive 1d4 weeks in the future. The crew is scattered across time. Reuniting them is a multi-session arc. The ones who arrived in the past have been living in the world, making decisions, for weeks. What did they do?

92-93 Rift Bloom. The exit portal doesn’t close. It grows. Over the next 1d4 days, it expands to consume a city block, then a neighborhood. A full-scale dimensional incursion begins. The crew is at ground zero. Corps scramble response teams. This is a major event.

94-95 The Other Side Noticed. Something intelligent, powerful, and not from any known dimension noticed the crew’s violent exit. It’s now watching them. It may begin communicating — through dreams, through their augments, through dimensional anomalies that appear specifically for the crew. Its motives are unknown. It is patient. This is a long-term campaign hook. ----------------------------------- -----------------------------------
96-100 — Reality Break
These should be extremely rare. The GM can choose to cap the table at 95 if they want.
Roll Result

96-97 Doppelganger. An exact duplicate of one crew member exits with the group. Same memories, same gear, same personality. Both believe they’re the original. One of them is a rift echo that will begin degrading in 1d4 weeks — but nobody knows which one. Not even the GM decides until it matters.

98 Dimensional Passenger. Something came through inside a crew member. They don’t know it yet. Over the next few sessions, they begin exhibiting unusual abilities, strange knowledge, and personality shifts. The passenger is intelligent. It has goals. It might be benign. It probably isn’t.

99 Everything Changed. The crew exits into a world that’s subtly wrong. A corporation that existed doesn’t anymore. A crew member’s contact has never heard of them. Street names are different. The city layout has shifted. The crew has exited into a parallel reality. Getting home — if home still exists — requires finding another rift.

100 The Big One. GM’s choice. The single most consequential event possible for the current campaign. A dimensional entity manifests. A corporation’s headquarters is swallowed by the rift. The crew gains permanent rift mutations. A dead NPC walks through the portal alive. The GM has been waiting for this. ----------------------------------- -----------------------------------
Design Notes

Why chaos instead of damage? Damage is boring and predictable. Players can calculate whether 2d6 is worth the risk. They can’t calculate “you might exit in the wrong dimension“ or “the boss followed you home.“ The d100 table makes violent extraction a genuine unknown — the kind of desperate choice that generates stories, not math.

Weighted toward bad. The table is intentionally skewed negative. 01-20 is favorable (20%). 21-45 is moderate (25%). 46-70 is serious (25%). 71-100 is catastrophic-to-reality-breaking (30%). Violent extraction should be a last resort, and the table enforces that through uncertainty, not guaranteed damage.
Reroll protection. If the GM has already used a result this campaign (especially 86+), they can either use the result again with different specifics or shift 1d10 up or down on the table.

Controlled extraction remains safe. The chaos table ONLY applies to violent extraction. Controlled extraction (3-turn charge) produces no table roll — it works as intended. The table is the price of panic.

“All materials recovered from rift zones remain the property of the contracting corporation unless otherwise specified in your agreement (see Clause 31: ’Resource Extraction Rights’). Unauthorized harvesting may constitute theft of corporate assets. Unauthorized gene-splicing with harvested materials constitutes a war crime in most jurisdictions. Most.“
Overview
Two new skills that create a full off-grid supply chain:

HARVESTING — Field extraction of materials from rift zones. Creature parts, exotic metals, dimensional crystals, anomalous substances, and — for the brave or stupid — genetic samples viable for bio-modification.
CRAFTING — Workshop fabrication. Turn raw materials into weapons, armor, ammo, consumables, traps, field equipment, and eventually vehicles and drones.

Together with Tech (installation) and Medicine (splicing), these skills complete the Contractor Workshop — a team that never needs to buy corporate products or visit corporate clinics. Everything sourced, built, and installed in-house. Off the grid. Off the books.

Material tier determines what you can craft. T1 materials make T1 gear. Mixing tiers is possible at higher Crafting skill levels.

Materials have weight and shelf life. Most materials need to be processed within 3-7 days or they degrade. Creature genetic samples degrade within 24 hours without preservation (Harvesting T3+ can preserve them). This creates urgency — you can’t stockpile forever.
🦴 HARVESTING (New Skill)

Primary Stat: Interface (knowledge of biology/materials) or Grit (physical extraction work — GM’s call based on context) Scope: Field extraction of rift materials, creature skinning/butchering, mineral harvesting, anomaly sampling, and genetic specimen collection.
You see a dead rift creature and think “that’s worth money.“ Everyone else sees a dead rift creature and thinks “please stop touching it.“

Not Gated — anyone can attempt to hack a piece off a dead creature. But without training, you’ll ruin the good stuff. Untrained harvesting: -2 to checks, and material tier is reduced by 1 (you get Common even from Uncommon sources).

🔨 CRAFTING (New Skill)

Primary Stat: Interface (design and precision) or Chrome (physical fabrication — GM’s call) Scope: Fabrication of weapons, armor, ammunition, consumables, traps, field equipment, and (at high tiers) vehicles and drones.

Gated (🔒): Cannot attempt without T1. Smashing two things together is not crafting. You need to understand materials, tools, and why the last person who tried this is missing fingers. You build things. Sometimes they work. The things that work are worth a fortune. The things that don’t work are worth a story.

The Wild Splice
This is the dangerous part. This is where someone looks at a rift creature’s venom glands and says “put that in me.“
What Is a Wild Splice?

A Wild Splice is an improvised mutation created from creature-harvested genetic material. No corporate testing. No safety data. No clinical trials. Just raw biological material from another dimension being shoved into a human body by someone with steady hands and questionable judgment.
Requirements

1. A Genetic Sample — harvested from a creature (Harvesting T2+). Must be preserved (Harvesting T3 Specimen Preservation, or used within 24 hours). 2. Processing (Optional but HIGHLY recommended) — a Crafter with Mutagenic Refiner (Crafting T3) processes the sample into a Refined Mutagen. This reduces complication DC by 2. 3. A Splicer — someone with Medicine T3 (Gene Splicer) or T4 (Biological Architect) to perform the procedure. 4. The Recipient — a contractor willing to have alien biology grafted into their body. Brave. Stupid. Both.
Wild Splice Rules
Wild Splices are ALWAYS Extreme Risk (DC 16) at minimum. The material is untested. Period.

Factor DC Modifier

Refined Mutagen (Crafting T3+)      -2

Biological Architect performing     Gene-doc tier + advantage on (Medicine T4)                       complication roll
Raw sample (unrefined)              +2

Best case scenario: Refined Mutagen + Biological Architect + proper workspace = DC 14, rolled with gene-doc tier. That’s still a 35% complication chance on a clean d20 — but manageable.

Worst case scenario: Raw sample from an unknown boss creature, spliced by a Gene Splicer in a back alley on a toxic recipient = DC 16 + 2 + 3 + 2 + 2 + 2 = DC 27. Impossible without divine intervention. Don’t do this. (Someone will do this.)
What Do You Get?
The GM determines the mutation based on the creature the sample came from. Wild Splices should:

1. Reflect the creature’s biology. Venom glands = poison ability. Armored hide = natural armor. Speed muscles = reflex boost. Wing membrane = gliding/jumping. Sensory organs = enhanced perception. 2. Always have a built-in cost (like all mutations). The cost should reflect the alien nature: your body is incorporating something that didn’t evolve for humans. 3. Be roughly equivalent to a High Risk or Extreme Risk mutation in power level. You’re getting creature biology — it should be potent. 4. Have unpredictable flavor. The mutation should feel alien. Not just “+1 Armor“ but “+1 Armor and your skin develops iridescent scales that shift color based on your mood and you smell like the creature for a week after installation.“

Wild Splice Failure
If the complication roll fails on a Wild Splice, use the standard Complication Tables from the Mutations system — but with one addition:

Wild Splice Critical Failure (fail by 12+): In addition to rolling on the Critical Complication table, the mutation is Unstable. Once per session, the GM can declare the mutation does something unexpected — the bonus activates when you don’t want it to, the creature’s instincts override yours for a moment, or the biological material expresses a secondary trait nobody anticipated. Unstable mutations can potentially be stabilized by a Biological Architect (Medicine T4) over multiple downtime periods (3 sessions of 2 AP treatment, 500 cr total). Until then, it’s a wild card.
The Harvester-Crafter Pipeline
Here’s how the full supply chain works when a team has both skills covered:
Scenario: Crafting a Rift-Crystal Blade

1. In the Rift: Harvester (T3) extracts reactive crystals (T2 material) from a dimensional anomaly. Rolls Interface check — full success, gets 3 units of quality crystal. 2. Back at Base: Crafter (T2 Weaponsmith) uses 2 units of crystal + standard metal components (50 cr) to forge a blade. Rolls Crafting check — 10+, Masterwork. Chooses bonus: “+1 accuracy vs rift creatures“ (the crystal resonates with dimensional energy). 3. Result: A custom weapon that would cost 400+ cr on the market, built for \~50 cr in purchased materials + free harvested materials + 4 AP total (2 harvesting, 2 crafting).
Scenario: Wild Splice from a Rift Stalker

1. In the Rift: Harvester (T3, Specimen Preservation) extracts adrenal glands from a killed Rift Stalker. Preserves the sample (good for 7 days). 2. Back at Base: Crafter (T3, Mutagenic Refiner) processes the raw sample into a Refined Mutagen. 2 AP, rolls check — success. DC reduced by 2. 3. The Splice: Field Doc (Medicine T3, Gene Splicer) performs the Wild Splice on a willing teammate. DC 16 - 2 (refined) = DC 14. Rolls 1d20 + Grit bonus… 4. Result: Either a contractor with alien adrenal glands and ambush instincts, or a contractor with alien adrenal glands, ambush instincts, AND a complication that makes their life interesting.
Scenario: Crafting Specialty Ammo Before a Mission

1. Downtime Day 1: Crafter (T2, Munitions Expert) has T2 materials from last mission’s harvest. Spends 1 AP crafting a batch of AP rounds (ignore 1 armor) and 1 AP crafting toxin rounds (+1 Poison on hit). 2. Cost: Materials only (\~40 cr for both batches). Market price for the same would be 150+ cr. 3. Result: Team goes into the next mission with specialized ammo at a fraction of the price. The Crafter still has 1 AP for study and 1 AP for sleep.
Harvesting During Missions
Harvesting isn’t just a downtime activity — it happens in the rift, during missions. This creates tension:
Harvesting takes time. A standard creature harvest takes 10-15 minutes (no AP cost in downtime terms, but real time during missions). Quick Skin (Harvesting T2) eliminates this delay.

Harvesting is sometimes illegal. Contracts may specify that all rift materials are corporate property. Harvesting for yourself is theft. Getting caught = contract violation, fines, blacklisting, or worse.
Contract Type Harvesting Status
Standard Extraction Contract All materials belong to the corp. Harvesting for yourself is theft.
Freelance/Bounty Contract You own what you find. Corp only pays for the objective.
Salvage Contract You’re specifically there to harvest. Corp takes a cut (usually 40-60%).
Unauthorized Entry No contract. Everything you find is yours. Everything that finds you is also yours to deal with. ----------------------------------- -----------------------------------

Smuggling harvested materials past corporate checkpoints requires a Stealth or Negotiate check (DC varies by material value and checkpoint security). Getting caught: fines (material value × 2), confiscation, and a black mark on your contractor record.
This creates another economic decision: follow the rules and buy materials at market price, or break the rules and source them for free with risk of getting caught. On-brand.
Interaction With Other Systems
Crafting + Tech (Chrome Tech path)
A Crafter who also has Tech T3 (Chrome Installer) can build AND install augments — fabricating the chrome components from harvested materials and putting them in. Total vertical integration.
Crafting + Medicine (Field Doc path)
A Crafter with Mutagenic Refiner who also has Medicine T3 (Gene Splicer) can process AND splice mutations. Harvest → Refine → Splice, all in one team.
Crafting + Economy
Crafted items sell at 60% of market price (not full — people know it’s homemade). But the profit margin is huge if materials were harvested for free:
• Harvest T2 materials (free)  • Craft T2 weapon (materials only, \~80 cr purchased components)  • Sell at 60% of 400 cr market price = 240 cr  • Profit: 160 cr per weapon
A dedicated Harvester-Crafter can fund the entire team’s downtime through crafting and selling.
Crafting + Downtime AP

Crafting is AP-efficient. Most items cost 1-2 AP to make. A crafter can produce 1-2 items per day while still sleeping and doing one other activity. Over a 7-day downtime, that’s 7-14 crafted items — enough to restock the team, sell surplus, and still train a skill.
Design Notes for GMs

Harvesting is a mission pacing tool. When the Harvester wants to stop and skin a creature, that takes time. Time the team might not have. “Do we let them harvest the Rift Stalker’s glands or do we push on before the breach closes?“ That’s a decision that matters.

Illegal harvesting creates heist energy. The team on a corporate extraction contract, sneaking creature parts past the checkpoint, is a whole sub-plot. Let it play out. The Negotiate contractor talks to the guards while the Harvester hides materials in the vehicle. The Stealth contractor plants decoys. This is content.

Wild Splices should be memorable. Don’t let them become routine. Each one should be a scene — the whole team watching while the Field Doc operates, the dice hitting the table, the moment of “did it work?“ And the mutation itself should feel unique, alien, personal. No two Wild Splices from the same creature type should be identical.

Crafting shouldn’t replace shopping entirely. Crafted items are cheaper and customizable, but they take time and materials. Corporate gear is expensive but instant and reliable. The choice between “I’ll build it over 3 days“ and “I’ll buy it right now for triple the price“ is the crafter’s constant dilemma.

Vehicle crafting is the endgame carrot. A team that builds their own rift-runner vehicle is a team that has invested heavily in downtime infrastructure. It should feel like an achievement — weeks of materials, thousands of credits in workshop upgrades, multiple crafting sessions. And then they have a vehicle with custom stats and a name they chose. That’s memorable.

“Unauthorized fabrication of weapons, armor, or biological modification compounds may violate your contractor agreement, local ordinances, and several interplanetary treaties. Please consult your corporate liaison before building anything that could be classified as a ’device,’ ’apparatus,’ or ’abomination.’ Thank you for your cooperation.“
